items.title: Randomly generate lines that are connected by nodes within a rectangle in java
items.body:
I'm currently working on a project that generates a flight route planning application. The player can generate up to 5 planes of two types, a small biplane, and a military jet, each plane having its own speed. The user will direct these planes to travel along randomly generated paths and visit each node, or city. Once a plane has visited all the cities, the player must have it return to it's starting point. If planes hit each other, the game is over. Right now, I have imported images of two different planes, created a function that generates a random amount of lines, generated a rectangle, and created two buttons that allow the user to import more planes of either type.

With the random line generator, I can only get the lines to generate on top of each other at one point. I want them to generate randomly within the rectangle and have them be connected so that when the planes travel along them and reach the end of each line, the player can have them move to the next line and so forth. I also need to have these lines generate within the rectangle, so bounds must be set for it. Any help would be appreciated.

My GUI class looks like the following:

public class GUI extends Application{

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        launch(args);

    }

    @Override
    public void start(Stage mainstage) throws Exception {
        // TODO Auto-generated method stub

        //Import the methods from the manager
        //class.
        Manager LineGenerator = new Manager();
        GridPane linePane = LineGenerator.LineGenerator();

        Manager PlaneInputMechanics = new Manager();
        GridPane buttonPane = PlaneInputMechanics.PlaneInputMechanics();

        //Generate a new GUI Window
        mainstage.setTitle("Flight Route Planning");
        mainstage.setHeight(1000);
        mainstage.setWidth(1500);
        mainstage.setResizable(true);

        //Generate a Rectangle for the game
        //to take place.
        Pane rectanglepane = RectangleField(mainstage);

        Scene rectanglescene = new Scene(rectanglepane);
        mainstage.setScene(rectanglescene);

        //Create a scene for the image import
        Image image = new Image("Cessna1Resized.jpg");
        ImageView imageView = new ImageView(image);
        GridPane mainImagePane = (GridPane) ImageImport(mainstage);
        mainImagePane.getChildren().add(imageView);

        mainImagePane.setTranslateX(300);
        mainImagePane.setTranslateY(300);

        Image image2 = new Image("MilitaryJet2Resized.jpg");
        ImageView image2View = new ImageView(image2);
        GridPane mainImage2Pane = (GridPane) ImageImport(mainstage);
        mainImage2Pane.getChildren().add(image2View);
        mainImage2Pane.setTranslateX(300);
        mainImage2Pane.setTranslateY(500);

        rectanglepane.getChildren().addAll(linePane, mainImagePane, mainImage2Pane, buttonPane);
        mainstage.show();       
    }


    /*Here, we generate a rectangle field that the 
     * random function will generate the lines and points
     * in.  Those parts cannot exceed the boundaries of the rectangle.
     */
    public Pane RectangleField(Stage mainstage) {

        //Generate a new Rectangle for the GUI
        //and move it to the center point of it.
        Rectangle rectangle = new Rectangle();
        rectangle.setHeight(900);
        rectangle.setWidth(1200);
        rectangle.setTranslateX(150);
        rectangle.setTranslateY(10);
        rectangle.setStroke(Color.BLACK);
        rectangle.setStrokeWidth(3);
        rectangle.setFill(Color.WHITE);

        //Create a Gridpane and input the rectangle
        //into it so it can be returned to start and run
        //correctly.
        GridPane rectanglegrid = new GridPane();
        rectanglegrid.getChildren().add(rectangle);

        return rectanglegrid;
    }

    //The purpose of this method is to import the images for the
    //different kinds of airplanes available within the program.
    //We use multiple kinds of aircraft to fulfill the inheritance
    //requirement of the project.

    public Pane ImageImport(Stage mainstage) {

        GridPane imagePane = new GridPane();
        Image image = new Image("file:Cessna1Resized.jpg");

        try {
            ImageView iv = new ImageView();
            iv.setImage(image);
            imagePane.getChildren().add(iv);


            } catch(Exception e) {
                e.printStackTrace();
            }

        imagePane.hgapProperty().set(100);
        imagePane.vgapProperty().set(100);

        imagePane.setMinSize(100, 100);

        GridPane image2Pane = new GridPane();
        Image image2 = new Image("file:MilitaryJet2Resized.jpg");
        try {
            ImageView iv2 = new ImageView();
            iv2.setImage(image2);
            image2Pane.getChildren().add(iv2);
        } catch(Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        image2Pane.hgapProperty().set(100);
        image2Pane.vgapProperty().set(100);

        image2Pane.setMaxSize(100, 100);
       return imagePane;
    }



    /*The purpose of this method is to initialize the
     * mechanics of the different planes.  The method 
     * inherits the properties from the ImageImport method
     * and sets the different types of images to different
     * speed properties.
     */
    public void PlaneMechanics() {

    }

    /*The purpose of this method is to program each plane to
     * follow the generated paths to each node, then switch to
     * another path based on how the Genetic algorithm's strategy
     * decides.
     */
    public void ImageLineFollow() {

    }

}

My Manager Class looks like this:

public class Manager {



    /*Here, we generate lines using the random
     * function.  We set the parameters of the random
     * to no more than 20 lines, or cities, each having at least 1
     * path connected to it.  The lines are then connected to 
     * randomized coordinates and set as paths for each plane to follow.
     */
    public GridPane LineGenerator() {
        Random RandomLine = new Random();

        int RandomLineCount = RandomLine.nextInt(20);

        GridPane LinePane = new GridPane();


        for(int x = 0; x <= RandomLineCount; x++) {

            Line LineCount = new Line(50,100+(10 * x),350,100);
            LineCount.setTranslateX(100);
            LineCount.setTranslateY(100);

            LinePane.getChildren().add(LineCount);
        }


        return LinePane;
    }

    public GridPane NodeGenerator(int LineCount, int RandomLineCount) {
        GridPane cityPane = new GridPane();

        for(int x = 0; x <= (RandomLineCount * 2); x++) {
        Circle cityNode = new Circle();
        cityNode.setRadius(2);
        cityNode.setStrokeWidth(10);
        cityNode.setTranslateX(LineCount);
        cityNode.setTranslateY(LineCount);
        cityPane.getChildren().add(cityNode);

        }

        return cityPane;
    }


    /*The purpose of this method is to enable the correct mechanics
     * that allows the user to input the number of planes they want
     * and the kinds that they would like. This will be linked to the
     * ImageInput method in the GUI class so that every time the user
     * presses a selection option, it generates a new image of the type
     * of plane selected. 
     */
    public GridPane PlaneInputMechanics() {
        GridPane buttonPane = new GridPane();
        Label buttonlabel = new Label();
        buttonlabel.setText("Input up to five planes of any type");
        buttonPane.getChildren().add(new Button("Cessna Plane"));
        buttonPane.getChildren().add(new Button("Military Jet"));


        return buttonPane;
    }

    public  void PlaneMotionMechanics() {

    }

}

  3. The 'test' string is never printed in the 'writeToOutFile' function, indicating the while loop is never called.

close(fd);

//have to work with the buffer
char outchar;

while(read(fd, &outchar, 1) > 0){ //change the buffer

}
close(fd);

What I have to do is verify my identity by getting a string-type challenge by the `GetAuthContext` call, then create a string-type signature using that challenge, and then pass that signature to the `Authenticate`call. The problem I'm having is that that I need to enter the return value of the `GetAuthContext` into the challenge parameter of the `create_signature` coroutine. Later this example gets assigned to connection.received ( `connection.received += on_debug` ) so I'm guessing that after `connection.start()` I have to put `connection.recieved()` to call the on_debug coroutine which will verify me, but for now I just want to understand how to reference the .invoke() methods to use within a function or coroutine.
items.title: How to reference/return a value from SignalR?
items.body:
This is the code I have:

from signalr_aio import Connection

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Create connection
    # Users can optionally pass a session object to the client, e.g a cfscrape session to bypass cloudflare.

    connection = Connection('https://beta.bittrex.com/signalr', session=None)
    hub = connection.register_hub('c2')

    hub.server.invoke('GetAuthContext', API_KEY)               #Invoke 0 Creates the challenge that needs to be signed by the create_signature coroutine
    signature = await create_signature(API_SECRET, challenge)  #Creates the signature that needs to authenticated in the Authenticate query
    hub.server.invoke('Authenticate', API_KEY, signature)      #Invoke 1 authenticates user to account level information

    connection.start()

What I have to do is verify my identity by getting a string-type challenge by the GetAuthContext call, then create a string-type signature using that challenge, and then pass that signature to the Authenticatecall. The problem I'm having is that that I need to enter the return value of the GetAuthContext into the challenge parameter of the create_signature coroutine. I'm guessing from the comment next to the below example that every invoke method gets marked as I([index of method]), so I would have to do signature = await create_signature(API_SECRET, 'I(0)')

async def on_debug(**msg):
    # In case of `queryExchangeState` or `GetAuthContext`
    if 'R' in msg and type(msg['R']) is not bool:
         # For the simplicity of the example I(1) corresponds to `Authenticate` and I(0) to `GetAuthContext`
         # Check the main body for more info.
         if msg['I'] == str(2):
            decoded_msg = await process_message(msg['R'])
            print(decoded_msg)
        elif msg['I'] == str(3):
            signature = await create_signature(API_SECRET, msg['R'])
            hub.server.invoke('Authenticate', API_KEY, signature)

Later this example gets assigned to connection.received ( connection.received += on_debug ) so I'm guessing that after connection.start() I have to put connection.recieved() to call the on_debug coroutine which will verify me, but for now I just want to understand how to reference the .invoke() methods to use within a function or coroutine.

items.title: C - usage of extern qualifier
items.body:
I have following three files. In the header file, I declare a global variable and tried to access it other files using extern. But I got the linker errors.

Header1.h

  #ifndef HEADER1_H
  #define HEADER1_H

  #include<stdio.h>

  int g = 10;
  void test();

  #endif

test.c

  #include "header1.h"

  extern int g;

  void test()
  {
       printf("from print function g=%d\n", g);
  }

main.c

  #include "header1.h"

  extern int g;

  int main()
  {
     printf("Hello World g=%d\n", g);
     test();
     getchar();
     return 0;
  }

Linker error:

  LNK2005   "int g" (?g@@3HA) already defined in main.obj   
  LNK1169   one or more multiply defined symbols found

My understanding about extern is that a variable can be defined only once but can be declared multiple times. I think I follow it this way - I defined the global variable g in the header file and tried to access it in the .c files.

Could you please correct my understanding? What actually causes the linker error here? I did not define g multiple times.

Then here is my question: is it possible to have multiple conda enviroment variables for the same project?  I give the following example to make my point much clearer: 

    pycharm_project_name

          def.py       (use conda environment variable: Caffe)

I am very new to verilog and am trying to make an 8x8 bit multiplier using the shift-add method.  I can't seem to get my code to work and I'm not sure if it's a syntax problem or just a logical error.  I also attached the testbench file as I'm not sure I'm doing that 100% correctly.  When I run the simulation it says all the inputs and outputs are z. UPDATE: I've added the instance to the testbench but I'm still getting z outputs and inputs.  

     `timescale 1ns / 1ps
      module lab6code(
        input [7:0] mp, mc,
        input start,
        output reg done,
        reg state,
        reg i, // i is the variable that gets used to check a specific bit in the mplier
        reg [15:0] x, //holder
        output reg [15:0] product,
        input clk);
    
    
    initial
     begin
        state=0;
        i=0;
        x=0;
     end

    always @(posedge clk)
    begin
        case(state)
        0:
        begin
            if(start==1)
                begin
                x[15:0] <= 4'b0000;
                x[7:0] <= mc; //assign multiplicand to holder
                state <= 1;
                end
        end
    
        1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15:
        begin
            if(x[i]==0) //checks specific place within mplier array, shifts and moves ahead 2 states
                begin
                 x = x << 1; //shifts mcand holder
                 state <= state+2; //moves ahead 2 states
                 i <= i + 1; //updates i so in the next case the next bit in mplier will be looked at
                end
            else //adds mplier and mcand, moves ahead one state
                begin
                 x[7:0] <= x + mp; //adds mplier to the mplier register
                 i <= i + 1; //updates i
                end
            
        end
    
        2, 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16: //shifts mcand and goes to next state
        begin
            x = x << 1; //shifts mcand holder
            state <= state + 1; // moves ahead one state
        end
    
        17:
            begin
            state <=0;
            done = 1;
            end
           endcase
    product = x;

    end   
 
 
    endmodule

Testbench:

    `timescale 1ns / 1ps

    module lab6tb(
    output product,
    reg start    );
    
    reg mp, mc;

    lab6code lab6code_instance(
    .mc(mc),
    .mp(mp),
    .product(product),
    .start(start)
    );


    initial
    begin 
    start = 1;
    mp = 7'b00001011;
    mc = 7'b00001001;
    end
    endmodule

items.title: C++ Win32 Console Color
items.body:
I know a bit how to do colors in Win32 C++ console. But it's not really efficient. For example:

 SYSTEM("color 01")

Slows down a lot on your process. Also:

 HANDLE h = GetStdHandle ( STD_OUTPUT_HANDLE );
 WORD wOldColorAttrs;
 CONSOLE_SCREEN_BUFFER_INFO csbiInfo;

 /*
  * First save the current color information
  */

 GetConsoleScreenBufferInfo(h, &csbiInfo);
 wOldColorAttrs = csbiInfo.wAttributes;

 /*
  * Set the new color information
  */

 SetConsoleTextAttribute ( h, FOREGROUND_RED );

Works great, but it doesn't have much colors. Also, FOREGROUND_RED is dark-red.

So what I want to ask, isn't there a way like CLR property Console::ForegroundColor set, so you can use any color from the ConsoleColor enum?

items.title: Map/Flatten Nested Attributes in Both Directions
items.body:
I have an entity class like:

class SomeEntity {
  int id;
  string name;
  date created;
}

and I have a dto class like:

class SomeDto {
   class SomeDtoAttributes {
      string name;
      date created;
   }

   string id;
   SomeDtoAttributes attributes;
}

Basically all properties on the Entity except for the id get put inside an attributes property on the dto.

I would like this mapper to be reusable for other entities/dtos that will follow the same pattern, but will have different properties.

I've read the documentation, but I am not clear on how to achieve this. Currently I have something like:

abstract class EntityMapper<DTO, DTOA E> {

    abstract E toEntity(DTO dto, DTOA attributes);

    abstract DTO toDto(E entity);

    abstract DTOA toDtoAttributes(E entity);

    abstract List<E> toEntityList(List<DTO> dtos);

    abstract List<DTO> toDtoList(List<E> entities);

    @AfterMapping
    protected void afterMapping(@MappingTarget DTO dto, E entity) {
        DTOA dtoAttributes = this.toDtoAttributes(entity);
        dto.setAttributes(dtoAttributes);
    }
}

But i don't like how I have to pass in both the dto and dtoAttributes in the toEntity method, and the toEntityList method doesn't populate the attribute properties on the returned entities.

items.title: Fetch with Credentials and Json Body
items.body:
Need to send a POST request with a JSON body. I have to use fetch.

Original code snippet, which worked:

headers = {'Content-Type': 'application/json'};
body = {path: 'path1'};
fetch(url, {
        method: 'post',
        headers: headers,
        body: JSON.stringify(body)
    })
        .then(response => {//do work});

Now I have to add Http-Only cookies for A&A.

This link has answer for that. Basically, have to add another parameter.

Afterwards updated code to: 

fetch(url, {
        credentials: 'include',
        method: 'post',
        headers: headers,
        body: JSON.stringify(body)
    })
        .then(response => {//do work});

Server doesn't see cookie in header.

Then tested the fetch by removing everything else:

fetch(url, {
        credentials: 'include',
        method: 'post',
    })
        .then(response => {//do work});

A&A part works i.e. Server now sees cookie in header. So, added the body back and didn't believe it would work:

body = {path: 'path1'};
fetch(url, {
        credentials: 'include',
        method: 'post',
        body: JSON.stringify(body)
    })
        .then(response => {//do work});

As expected, it didn't work. The Express server with CookieParser is showing that body is {}.

After added the Content-Type header:

body = {path: 'path1'};
fetch(url, {
        credentials: 'include',
        method: 'post',
        headers: {'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
        body: JSON.stringify(body)
    })
        .then(response => {//do work});

Now, the cookie has disappeared again. Guessing it's because of adding a new header, and replacing header generated by fetch, which includes cookie. Am I wrong?

While I was searching I found a similar question with no answer.

How should I proceed?

I'm having an issue where I can't seem to bind the numeric variables to a JPA hibernate query, like I do for any string type variables.

`Predicate predicate = cb.equal(root.get("age"), age); //int variable
 predicate = cb.equal(root.get("name"), name); //string variable`

The query hibernate creates:

`select * from ( select emp0_.emp_id as emp_id1_10_0_, 
                 empdeta1_.emp_name as emp_name1_25_1_, 
                 empdeta1.emp_age as emp_age1_10_0 
                 where empdeta1.emp_name=? 
                 and empdeta1.emp_age=25 ) 
 where rownum <= ?`

So, as we can see, emp_name is having a proper bind variable while age does not. It gets hard coded as a literal.

Has anyone, else also faced this issue?
items.title: JPA Hibernate does not bind numeric variable like it does for string variable
items.body:

select * from ( select emp0_.emp_id as emp_id1_10_0_, empdeta1_.emp_name as emp_name1_25_1_, empdeta1.emp_age as emp_age1_10_0 where empdeta1.emp_name=? and empdeta1.emp_age=25 ) where rownum <= ?
